coredata.dc:title: Photocatalytic production of H2O2 from water and dioxygen only under visible light using organic polymers: Systematic study of the effects of heteroatoms
coredata.dc:creator: Kim, Hyejin
Shim, Kyuin
Lee, Kyoung Eun
Han, Jeong Woo
Zhu, Yongfa
Choi, Wonyong
coredata.dc:description: The photocatalytic production of H2O2 that needs dioxygen, water, and light only has been proposed and investigated. However, most of the studies employed organic electron donors. In this work, organic photocatalysts that can produce H2O2 without organic electron donors are designed with a bottom-up approach. Although the heptazine-based g-C3N4 cannot induce water oxidation, a different kind of organic polymer (CN) obtained from the condensation of s-triazine and pyrimidine can produce H2O2 via dioxygen reduction coupled with water oxidation. The incorporation of O and P elements in CN structure (CNO, CNP, CNOP) increases the visible light absorption and hinders the photodecomposition of H2O2, respectively. The C-O and P-O bonds act as the charge trapping sites and also the preferred adsorption sites of a key intermediate, •OOH. As a result, the CNOP exhibits the highest production of H2O2 using dioxygen, water, and visible light only.

xocs:item-toc-entry.xocs:item-toc-section-title: Analyses of ORR with OER on organic polymers
Effect of heteroatoms on organic polymers for H2O2 production

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (a) XRD spectra and (b) ATR FT-IR spectra of CNOP, CNO, CNP, CN, and g-C3N4 (c) ATR FT-IR spectra of HTP, BA, CC, Cyanuric acid, TP, and Melamine precursors. (d) Tauc plots for the bandgap analysis and (e) the electronic band positions of CNOP, CNO, CNP, CN, and g-C3N4.

(a) The time profiles of photosynthetic production of H2O2 up to 12 h and (b) a longer period (50 h) ([catalyst] = 0.5 g/L; O2-purged under visible light irradiation (λ > 420 nm)). (c) The time profiles of photocatalytic decomposition of H2O2 ([catalyst] = 0.5 g/L, [H2O2]0 = 1 mM; Ar-purged under visible light irradiation (λ > 420 nm)). (d) The apparent quantum yields of H2O2 production under monochromatic light irradiation for CNOP, CNO, CNP and CN. ([catalyst] = 0.5 g/L; O2-purged under visible light irradiation (λ > 420 nm)).

(a) Time profiles of H2O2 production on CNOP under different dissolved gas conditions. (b) The formation of H2O2 in different mixtures of water and acetonitrile solvent under O2-purged condition ([catalyst] = 0.5 g/L; visible light irradiation (λ > 420 nm)). (c) Time profiles of PEC O2 production in the photoanode compartment of CNOP, CNO, CNP and CN in an unbiased system under visible light. ([NaClO4] = 0.5 M; Pre-purged Ar in the anode compartment.).

(a) Photocurrent response time profiles of the catalyst-coated FTO electrode. The yellow-shaded area indicates the light irradiation period. The experimental conditions were [NaClO4] = 0.5 mM with potential bias of – 0.4 V (vs Ag/AgCl) under Ar- or O2-purging. (b) PL emission spectra (λex = 400 nm) of CNOP, CNO, CNP and CN. (c) Koutecky-Levich plots of CNOP, CNO, CNP and CN electrode obtained by RDE measurement with continuous O2 purging at − 0.4 V (vs Ag/AgCl). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)
Binding sites of •OOH intermediate on the (a) CNOP, (b) CNO, (c) CNP, and (d) CN.
Precursors for the synthesis of organic polymer photocatalysts of (a) CNOP, (b) CNO, (c) CNP, (d) CN, and (e) g-C3N4.

head.ce:title: Photocatalytic production of H2O2 from water and dioxygen only under visible light using organic polymers: Systematic study of the effects of heteroatoms

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The photocatalytic production of H2O2 that needs dioxygen, water, and light only has been proposed and investigated. However, most of the studies employed organic electron donors. In this work, organic photocatalysts that can produce H2O2 without organic electron donors are designed with a bottom-up approach. Although the heptazine-based g-C3N4 cannot induce water oxidation, a different kind of organic polymer (CN) obtained from the condensation of s-triazine and pyrimidine can produce H2O2 via dioxygen reduction coupled with water oxidation. The incorporation of O and P elements in CN structure (CNO, CNP, CNOP) increases the visible light absorption and hinders the photodecomposition of H2O2, respectively. The C-O and P-O bonds act as the charge trapping sites and also the preferred adsorption sites of a key intermediate, •OOH. As a result, the CNOP exhibits the highest production of H2O2 using dioxygen, water, and visible light only.

ce:section.ce:para: Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is a relatively stable reactive oxygen species having an intermediate oxidation state between water and dioxygen. H2O2 has been widely used as a green oxidant in industrial, chemical, and environmental applications such as pulp bleaching, organic synthesis, and advanced oxidation process for wastewater treatment. The commercial production of H2O2 is mostly based on the anthraquinone process, however, it has disadvantages such as the need for H2 gas, noble metal catalysts and organic solvents, and the production of wastewater [1]. The semiconductor photocatalysis can be employed as an eco-friendly method to produce H2O2 by oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) using photo-generated electrons without the need for H2. This method needs photocatalyst, water, dioxygen, and light only.

Metal oxide-based semiconductors have been investigated for the photo-production of H2O2 via ORR but they generally have high adsorption affinity for H2O2, which facilitates the in-situ photocatalytic decomposition of H2O2 and limits the overall production of H2O2 under irradiation. As an alternative photocatalyst, metal-free organic polymer semiconductors such as carbon nitride (g-C3N4) with a low adsorption affinity for H2O2 (hence low photoactivity for H2O2 decomposition) have been proposed for the production of H2O2. However, g-C3N4 has no activity for water photooxidation and needs organic electron donors for the production of H2O2 through ORR [2–4]. Therefore, it is necessary to design an organic polymer photocatalyst that can utilize water as an electron donor (i.e., water oxidation) for the selective ORR to H2O2. Modification of organic polymer photocatalysts has been tried in various ways to enhance the photoactivity. For example, g-C3N4 photocatalysts modified with heteroatoms such as potassium, phosphorus, oxygen, and sulfur were prepared to increase both the efficiency and selectivity of H2O2 production [5–8]. The heteroatoms incorporation enhances the adsorption of O2, increases the charge carrier lifetime, and inhibits the decomposition of H2O2 by changing the chemical properties of g-C3N4 such as charge polarization and active sites. Oxygen-enriched g-C3N4 that was synthesized by using ammonium paratungstate as dopant increased the production efficiency of H2O2 [9]. However, most of the modified g-C3N4 photocatalysts need organic electron donors (e.g., alcohols) to produce H2O2.

According to the calculated free energy changes for the intermediate reaction steps during the water oxidation, tri-s-triazine based g-C3N4 needs the additional external potential to oxidize water [2]. To make water oxidation possible, therefore, cobalt-based co-catalysts (e.g., Co(OH)2, Co3O4, CoP, and impregnated cobalt ions) have been loaded on g-C3N4 for lowering thermodynamic barriers [10–14]. As another strategy for water oxidation using g-C3N4, the pyromellitic diimide (PDI) was incorporated into g-C3N4 to shift VB positively from that of bare g-C3N4, which enabled water oxidation with H2O2 production [15]. To further improve the efficiency, biphenyl diimide (BDI) instead of PDI was also incorporated into g-C3N4 [16]; g-C3N4/PDI was hybridized with reduced graphene oxide (rGO) which acts as not only a trap site for CB electron and but also an active site for O2 reduction [17]. As an alternative to g-C3N4, polymeric resorcinol-formaldehyde (RF) resin has been demonstrated for the photocatalytic production of H2O2 from O2 and water [18]. The photocatalytic efficiencies of H2O2 production reported in the literature are summarized in Supplementary Table 1.

On the other hand, s-triazine based carbon nitride is able to facilitate water oxidation without the aid of any co-catalyst according to theoretical investigations [19,20]. In this work, we employ s-triazine and pyrimidine as monomers to synthesize a new kind of carbon and nitrogen-based polymers (CN) which have significantly higher visible light absorption than tri-s-triazine based g-C3N4 and can oxidize water under visible light [21]. To further promote the efficiency and selectivity of H2O2 production, heteroatoms such as oxygen and phosphorus are incorporated in CN framework by using the precursors that are modified to contain O and P elements. The CN polymer incorporated with O and P elements (CNOP) was synthesized and tested for CO2 reduction under visible light but it needed triethanolamine as a sacrificial electron donor [22]. In the present study, the derivatives of CN polymers incorporated with O and/or P heteroelements (denoted as CNO, CNP, and CNOP) were prepared and tested for the photosynthesis of H2O2 without organic electron donors. All CN-based organic polymers are stronger visible light absorbers than g-C3N4 and enable the photosynthesis of H2O2 without the need of organic electron donors. In particular, the co-incorporation of O and P in CNOP markedly enhances the photoactivity of H2O2 synthesis. The effects of phosphorus and oxygen heteroelements incorporated in the CN polymers were investigated systematically for the photosynthesis of H2O2 coupled with water oxidation under visible light.

Organic polymers were synthesized through the condensation reaction of two precursors as shown in Scheme 1. Two mmoles of hexachlorocyclotriphosphazene (HTP, Sigma-Aldrich, 99% purity) (for CNOP and CNP) or cyanuric chloride (CC, Sigma-Aldrich, 99% purity) (for CNO and CN) and six mmoles of barbituric acid (BA, Sigma-Aldrich, 99% purity) (for CNOP and CNO) or triamino pyrimidine (TP, Sigma-Aldrich, 97% purity) (for CNP and CN) were mixed in 70 mL acetonitrile (Sigma-Aldrich, anhydrous, 99.8% purity) and stirred for 12 h. This mixture was heated at 180 °C for 48 h with a heating rate of 5 °C/min to carry out the condensation reaction hydrothermally. The synthesized product was filtrated and washed with water several times by repeated centrifugation at 16,000 rpm. The final product was dried at 80 °C overnight. Bare g-C3N4 was also synthesized as a control sample to be compared with CN, CNO, CNP, and CNOP through calcining 3 g melamine (Sigma-Aldrich, 99% purity) in an alumina crucible at 550 °C for 2 h with a heating and cooling rate of 5 °C/min [23].

The functional groups of the synthesized polymers were analyzed by attenuated total reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR, Thermo Scientific iS50). Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured by an X-ray diffractometer (RIGAKU D MAX 2500) with Cu Kα radiation. The solid-state 13C CPMAS and 31P MAS spectra were acquired on a 400 MHz solid-state NMR spectrometer (AVANCE III HD, Bruker, Germany) with a 4 mm HX-MAS probe. Diffuse reﬂectance UV–visible absorption spectra (DR-UVS) were obtained using a spectrophotometer (Shimadzu UV-2401PC) equipped with an integrating sphere attachment. BaSO4 was used as a reference. The valence band edge position was estimated by ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS, QM12) using monochromatic He I (21.2 eV) radiation as an excitation source. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using a monochromated Al-Kα line (1486.6 eV) as an excitation source. The surface area and pore volume of the polymer samples were measured using a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller N2 sorption analyzer (Mirae SI nanoPorosity-XQ analyzer). The dynamic light scattering (DLS) data were collected using a Zeta-potential & Particle Size Analyzer (ELS-1000) from Otsuka Electronics. Photoluminescence (PL) emission spectra were collected using a fluorescence spectrophotometer (Shimadzu RF-5301).

To carry out the photosynthetic production of H2O2 through the reduction of O2, the catalyst powder (20 mg) was dispersed in deionized water (40 mL, 0.5 g/L) under ultrasonication, and then exposed to the irradiation from a 300-W Xe arc lamp (Oriel) which passed through a 10-cm water filter and a long pass cutoff filter (λ > 420 nm, 350 mW/cm2). Sample aliquots of 0.5 mL were withdrawn at predetermined time intervals from the reactor and filtered by a 0.45 µm filter (Millipore) to remove catalyst particles. The concentration of H2O2 was determined by a colorimetric method using N,N-diethyl-1,4-phenylene-diamine sulfate (DPD). An aliquot of the solution was immediately mixed with phosphate buffer, DPD solution, and peroxidase under vigorous stirring for 90 s, then the absorbance was monitored at 551 nm using a UV/visible spectrophotometer (Libra S22, Biochrom). To measure the generated O2 in the slurry-type, dissolved oxygen (DO) meter (Thermo Scientific VSTAR) was used. The apparent quantum yield (AQY) of H2O2 production was calculated through the equation: ΦAQY(%) = ([number of produced H2O2 molecules]×2)/[number of incident photons] × 100. The incident wavelength was adjusted by a monochromator (Newport, Oriel 77250) and the light intensity was measured with a low-power detector (Newport, 818-UV). For the calculation of solar-to-chemical conversion (SCC) efficiency, the photoreactions were performed in pure water contained catalysts (0.5 g/L) under continuous O2 purging with a solar simulator PEC-L01 (Peccell Technologies). The SCC efficiency was calculated through the equation: SCC efficiency(%) = [ΔG for H
2
O
2
generation (J mol
−1
)]•[produced H
2
O
2
(mol)]/[total input energy (W)][reaction time (s)] × 100 [24].

For the photocurrent measurement, the photoelectrodes were fabricated using a spin-coating method with applying an aliquot of suspension (2 mg in 2 mL ethanol with 50 µL Nafion solution) onto a cleaned fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) and then heated at 200 °C for 10 min. The photocurrent was measured using the fabricated photoelectrode, a coiled Pt wire, and a Ag/AgCl electrode as a working, a counter, and a reference electrode, respectively. The photoelectrode was biased with a potential of −0.4 V (vs Ag/AgCl) in continuously Ar- or O2- purged electrolyte solution (0.5 M Na2SO4) under visible light irradiation (λ > 420 nm).

A separate photoelectrochemical (PEC) reaction test was performed to confirm the O2 generation from water oxidation under visible light irradiation (λ > 420 nm) in a three-electrode cell (unbiased) with two compartments separated by Nafion membrane (Membrane Nafion N117). The headspace gaseous products (O2) in the photoelectrode compartment were withdrawn by 100 µL syringe (Hamilton 81030) and quantified using a gas chromatograph (GC, HP6890A) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a 5 Å-molecular sieve column.

The selectivity of electron transfer to dioxygen was analyzed by electrochemical rotating disk electrode (RDE) voltammetry in 0.1 M KOH solution under an O2-purged condition. An ethanol solution containing Nafion ionomer was prepared for dispersing the catalyst with a mass ratio of 1:0.3 (Nafion: catalyst). The prepared slurry was loaded on a glassy carbon disk electrode (3 mm diameter, ALS Co., no. 011169) with the catalyst loading of 20 µg/cm2, which acted as a working electrode. A Ag/AgCl electrode and a platinum wire were used as a reference electrode and a counter electrode, respectively. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSVL CHI 660E potentiostat) was measured with a scan rate of 10 mV/s from −0.6 to 0.2 V at different rotating speeds using a rotating ring disk electrode rotator (RRDE-3A, ALS Co., Ltd). To determine the electron transfer number, the slope of the Koutecky-Levich (KL) plot was estimated from a linear correlation between j −1 and ω −1/2 (j: current density, ω: angular velocity of the disk electrode).

All density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out using the Vienna ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP) [25]. The Perdew-Burke Ernzerhof (PBE) functional of the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was used for the electronic exchange and correlation energies [26,27]. A plane-wave basis set with the energy cutoff of 400 eV was used, and Monkhorst-Pack 4 × 10 × 6 k-point meshes were used [28]. For the structural optimization, all atoms were relaxed using a conjugate-gradient algorithm until the difference in the total force was < 0.03 eV/Å [29]. Moreover, one negative charge was added to illustrate the charged characteristic of perhydroxyl radical, •OOH. Adsorption energies, Eads were calculated using the equation of (Eads = Etot – Ebare – E•OOH), where Ebare is the total energy of bare surface such as CNOP, CNP, CN and CNO, E•OOH the total energy of •OOH, and Etot the total energy of •OOH adsorbed on the bare surface. Lastly, VESTA package was used for visualization [30].

C, N, O, P-based organic polymer (CNOP) was prepared via condensation reaction of HTP and BA. To investigate the effects of O and P elements in CNOP on the photoactivity of H2O2 production, the CNO, CNP, and CN polymers were also synthesized by using different precursors (see Scheme 1). The crystalline structure of the synthesized organic polymers was characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) analysis ( Fig. 1a). The main peak around 27° is ascribed to the interlayer stacking which slightly varies depending on the kind of organic polymer [31]. The FT-IR analysis in Fig. 1b confirmed that these organic polymers were synthesized by the bond formation between two precursors through a chemical reaction. The IR peaks ascribed to the pyrimidine structure in all polymers and the triazine structure in CNO and CN are shown in the region between 1200 and 1620 cm−1, which correspond to the stretching vibrations of heterocyclic CN [32]. The precursors of pyrimidine and triazine such as BA, CC, and TP exhibit strong IR absorption peaks around that region as shown in Fig. 1c. The original PN peak from cyclotriphosphazene ring corresponds to the band at 1242 cm−1. The newly formed P–O, C–O, P–N, and C–N structural units in CNOP, CNO, CNP, and CN from condensation reaction correspond to the IR peaks at 996, 1066, 1100, and 1300 cm−1, respectively [22,33,34].

To confirm whether the polymers are synthesized from the condensation reaction of two precursors, the solid-state 13C NMR and 31P NMR were carried out as shown in Fig. S1. When BA reacted with HTP for CNOP synthesis, the pyrimidine as a tautomeric form of BA was observed. In Fig. S1a and S1b, the 13C NMR of CNOP demonstrated three peaks of pyrimidine as a tautomeric form of barbituric acid (indicated by the red circles), resulted from the reaction of BA (indicated by the red triangle) [35]. The blue square signal at around 40 ppm in BA was shifted to 79.5 ppm, which is typical of a CH group in sp2 hybridization in pyrimidine. The CNO also exhibits similar peaks by the pyrimidine formation from BA. These peaks are overlapped with cyanuric acid peaks representing oxygen-connected triazine in the CNO polymer. In the case of CNP and CN, the two main peaks around 167 and 161 ppm were generated from the polymerization of triamino pyrimidine with other precursors [36,37]. These peaks are overlapped with melamine representing the nitrogen-connected triazine in CN polymer. From 31P NMR in Fig. S1c, the newly generated bond with phosphorus was detected with the original bond of P–N in the cyclotriphosphazene ring at −0.12 ppm. The newly formed P-O bond (CNOP) and P-N bond (CNP) show the peaks at −10.88 ppm and −10.4 ppm which are very closely positioned [22,38].

The bandgap size was estimated from DR-UVS (Fig. 1d), the valence band edge position from UPS, and the conduction band edge position from the Mott-Schottky plot (see Fig. S2). All these organic polymers (CN, CNO, CNP, and CNOP) have the band edge potentials that are capable of both oxidizing water (E0(O2/H2O) = 1.23 VNHE) and reducing O2 (E0(O2/H2O2) = 0.67 VNHE) and have higher visible light absorption capacity than g-C3N4 (see Fig. 1d and e). The co-incorporation of O and P in CNOP significantly lowered the bandgap with enhancing the visible light absorption. Even if the energy difference between the valence band maximum (VBM) and the water oxidation potential is only 0.1–0.2 V, it was reported that the water oxidation with 0.1 V overpotential is possible [39–41].

The texture properties (surface area, total pore volume) of the polymers were also investigated (see Fig. S3a). The BET surface area of CNO and CNP was higher than that of the bare CN (14.83 m2/g) but CNOP (14.86 m2/g) was similar to CN in the surface area. On the other hand, as for the particle size in the aqueous suspension (Fig. S3b), CNOP showed the smallest particle size, and CNO, CNP, and CN followed in order. The well-dispersed CNOP particles in water might enhance the overall photocatalytic conversion efficiency.

The visible light irradiation to the catalyst suspension induced the production of H2O2 and all samples of CN, CNP, CNO, and CNOP can produce H2O2 from the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in the absence of any organic electron donors, whereas g-C3N4 (a control sample synthesized from melamine) was completely inactive despite its proper band edge positions for water oxidation and ORR ( Fig. 2a) [2]. Among them, CNOP that exhibits the highest visible light absorption capacity shows the highest activity of H2O2 production (Fig. 2a) and the lowest activity for the photodecomposition of H2O2 (Fig. 2c). The precursor ratio of 2: 6 (HTP: BA) for CNOP was chosen as an optimal composition. The pH was not controlled because the initial pH of about 3.5 was in the optimal range (see Fig. S4) and the suspensions of other catalysts were also in the similar acidic pH (CNO: 4.6, CNP: 3.9, CN: 3.7). Meanwhile, only CNOP exhibited the sustained production of H2O2 up to 50 h whereas the photo-activity of CN and CNO were gradually reduced beyond 12 h irradiation as shown in Fig. 2b. The performance of CNOP for H2O2 production under AM 1.5 G simulated solar irradiation (100 mW/cm2) was also tested, which was higher than under the visible light irradiation (λ > 420 nm). The SCC efficiency of CNOP as artificial photosynthesis of H2O2 was calculated showing 0.05% at an early stage (~3 h).

The overall production of H2O2 is also influenced by how fast in-situ generated H2O2 is photocatalytically decomposed. The photo-activities of the H2O2 decomposition are compared in Fig. 2c. While CNO has a markedly higher photoactivity of H2O2 decomposition, CNOP and CNP that contain phosphorous exhibited very low activities for the photodecomposition of H2O2. It should be noted that CNP and CNOP polymers contain the structure units similar to phosphoric triamides and phosphorus triamides that are known as a stabilizer of aqueous H2O2 solution [42]. Such structural characteristics of CNOP and CNP are expected to play a role in stabilizing the produced H2O2 against its photodecomposition. This is consistent with the observation that the photoproduction of H2O2 on CNOP was higher in phosphate buffer solution (10 mM at pH 7) than that without phosphate at the same pH (see Fig. S4b). While the presence of phosphate enhanced the production of H2O2, the addition of NaCl and Na2SO4 (10 mM) had no effect. This implies that the phosphate species enhances the production of H2O2 through hindering the decomposition of the in-situ generated H2O2. The phosphorous center incorporated within CNP and CNOP seems to play the similar role. Furthermore, the CNOP in phosphate buffer solution showed enhanced H2O2 production (see Fig. S4b). In conclusion, CNOP show the lowest decomposition rate among these organic polymers with the highest H2O2 production rate (see Fig. S5). Furthermore, CNOP exhibited the highest apparent quantum yield (ΦAQY) of H2O2 production over the wavelength range of 400–600 nm (Fig. 2d). The FT-IR and XPS analysis of the polymer photocatalysts before and after 12 h photoreaction confirmed their stability (Fig. S6 and S7).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Analyses of ORR with OER on organic polymers
ce:section.ce:para:
The photocatalytic production of H2O2 on CNOP was the highest under O2-saturated condition and negligible under continuously Ar-purged condition ( Fig. 3a). In the air-saturated condition, CNOP exhibited 80% of the efficiency achieved under O2-saturated condition. This clearly indicates that H2O2 production needs O2 as a precursor, which should proceed through 2-electron reduction of ORR (Eq. 1). Although a small level of H2O2 was generated even under the initially Ar-purged condition, the in-situ photo-oxidation of water (Eq. 2) seems to provide O2 for H2O2 production. Under continuously Ar-purged condition where in-situ generated O2 would be immediately removed, no H2O2 was produced, which confirms the role of in-situ generated O2. The possibility of H2O2 production from water oxidation can be ruled out by the fact that CNOP could not produce H2O2 at all under continuous Ar purging. A similar phenomenon was also confirmed for CNP, CN, and CNO as shown in Fig. S8.
(1) 2O2 + 4H+ + 4e− → 2H2O2
(2) 2H2O → O2 + 4H+ + 4e−
(3) O2 + 2H2O → 2H2O2

The fact that H2O2 was generated via O2 reduction in the absence of organic electron donors under irradiation implies that water should be concurrently photo-oxidized to serve as an electron donor through oxygen evolution reaction (OER) (Eq. 2). Although chloride impurities remaining from the catalyst synthesis procedure might be oxidized serving as an electron donor, no free chlorine species resulting from chloride oxidation were detected (using the DPD colorimetric method for H2O2 detection excluding peroxidase) [43]. Even adding 10 mM NaCl to CNOP suspension neither generated free chlorine species nor enhanced the production of H2O2. This should rule out the possible role of chlorides as an electron donor. To further confirm the role of water photooxidation in the photosynthetic production of H2O2 on CNOP, acetonitrile was used as an alternative solvent instead of water. The result in Fig. 3b shows that H2O2 production was not observed at all in 100% acetonitrile solution, which means that CNOP needs water as a source of electrons and protons to generate H2O2. When the water content in acetonitrile was gradually increased, the photoproduction of H2O2 increased. However, the water content higher than 60% decreased the H2O2 production efficiency, which might be ascribed to the fact that the oxygen solubility in acetonitrile is 7.6 times higher than in water under air-saturated condition [44]. The lower concentration of dissolved O2 should retard ORR that leads to the production of H2O2. It is also noticeable that pH is not changed after a long time photoreaction (initial and final pH were 3.5). Other catalysts (CNO, CNP, and CN) also showed the same final pH as the initial one. This proves that protons that are consumed for H2O2 production (Eq. 1) are continuously supplied through water oxidation (Eq. 2), which results in the overall reaction (Eq. 3) that should be little dependent on pH (see Fig. S4b).

To directly confirm the evolution of O2 from the photooxidation of water (OER) in deaerated suspension of CNOP, the concentration of dissolved O2 was monitored during the irradiation but the in-situ generated [O2] was maintained below 0.2 mg/L. Such a low level of O2 production implies that in-situ generated O2 is immediately consumed for H2O2 production. The addition of Ag+ ions as an electron acceptor should facilitate the OER and consequently enhanced the production of O2 (Fig. S9). The dark control test confirmed that possible air leaking was negligible. As the O2 level was low in the photocatalytic suspension system, the O2 gas production from OER was also measured using a two-compartment PEC cell (Fig. 3c). This PEC cell included a catalyst-coated photoanode and a Pt wire cathode without an externally biased potential, which should inhibit the consumption of in-situ generated O2 (ORR) for H2O2 production. The O2 production should not be ascribed to air leaking as the dark control experiment showed no production of O2 as shown in Fig. S10. The photo-generated electrons in the anode move to the cathode and the holes remaining in the photoanode can oxidize water to dioxygen. The order of dioxygen production efficiency is almost similar to that of H2O2 production among the polymer photocatalysts and CNOP exhibited the highest activities in the photogeneration of both H2O2 and O2. All the experimental data shown in Fig. 3 strongly support that H2O2 should be produced photocatalytically via O2 reduction with the concurrent water oxidation as a source of electrons and protons.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Effect of heteroatoms on organic polymers for H2O2 production
ce:section.ce:para: To investigate the selectivity of the oxygen reduction on the photocatalysts, the photocurrent response under negative bias potential was measured using the catalyst-coated electrode. Fig. 4a shows that the photocurrent generated in Ar-purged condition is negligible but that in O2-purged condition is highly enhanced. In particular, the CNOP electrode exhibited the highest enhancement of photocurrent, which means that dioxygen can effectively scavenge photo-generated electrons on the polymer electrode surface. CNOP shows the highest charge separation efficiency in O2-purged condition. Therefore, it is clearly demonstrated that CNOP is highly active for ORR as well as OER, which enables the O2 reduction to H2O2 along with O2 evolution from water oxidation.

To confirm the charge separation behaviour, steady-state PL of polymers was investigated (Fig. 4b). The PL spectrum of CN and CNP shows similar emission intensity, whereas that of CNO is red-shifted with reduced intensity and that of CNOP is almost completely quenched [45]. It means that the C–O bond in CNO and C–O and P–O bond in CNOP serve as the charge trapping site. Through the DFT calculation, the binding site and adsorption energy of •OOH, which represents the adsorbed intermediate during ORR or OER in the unit cell of the polymers, are estimated shown in Fig. 5. The calculation results indicate that the preferred adsorption site of •OOH in CN is on the carbon atom, and the preferred C site is not changed even after the incorporation of O or P (in CNO and CNP). As the charge trapping site should be mainly associated with C–O and P-O bonds, the adsorption of •OOH on the C site that is not bonded with O atom should not lead to the successful ORR or OER. However, the CNOP incorporated with both O and P exhibits the preferred binding sites of •OOH at the phosphorus (P-O bond) as well as the carbon (C–O bond). As a result, the adsorbed •OOH on the P and C sites can be effectively transformed to H2O2 or O2 via reacting with trapped electrons/holes in the C–O and P–O bond in CNOP. Furthermore, from the RDE measurement, the electron transfer number (n) to dioxygen could be calculated using Koutecky-Levich plots. In Fig. 4c, CN, CNP, and CNOP exhibited the n value very close to 2.0 while CNO showed a lower value (n = 1.56). This explains why CNO shows a lower efficiency of H2O2 production than CN, even though the PL intensity of CNO is lower (i.e., retarded recombination) than that of CN.

Photocatalysts that produce H2O2 from water, dioxygen, and sunlight only are being actively sought as a green solution that can replace the traditional anthraquinone process. Various semiconductors based on metal oxides or g-C3N4 have been investigated for this purpose but they need organic electron donors to reduce O2 to H2O2. In this work, a different kind of carbon and nitrogen-based organic polymer (CN) and the derivatives incorporated with O and/or P elements (CNO, CNP, and CNOP) were synthesized as photocatalysts that enable the photosynthesis of H2O2 without the need of organic electron donors under visible light irradiation. These organic polymers composed of C, N, O, and P are uniquely different from g-C3N4 in that they can absorb visible light more strongly and are able to produce H2O2 without the need of organic electron donors. Compared with CN, CNO and CNP were less active for the production of H2O2 but CNOP exhibited a markedly enhanced activity through two-electron ORR coupled with water oxidation. The incorporation of O and/or P elements influences not only the production of H2O2 through ORR but also the photodecomposition of H2O2. The oxygen incorporation in CNO (C-O bond) significantly increases the H2O2 decomposition rate but introducing the phosphorus element in the organic polymer (CNP) almost completely inhibits the decomposition of H2O2 on the contrary. Although CNP has a merit of hindered decomposition of H2O2, which is a preferred property for H2O2 production, it has much reduced visible light absorption and hence the lowest photoactivity of H2O2 production. However, the co-incorporation of O and P not only enhanced the visible light absorption but also hindered the photodecomposition of H2O2. The C-O and P-O bonds in CNOP act as not only the charge trapping sites but also the preferred adsorption sites of •OOH which is a key intermediate for both ORR and OER. Therefore, CNOP can effectively use the trapped charges for the production of H2O2 and O2. The unique effects of phosphorus and oxygen heteroelements in the CN polymer structure should be considered as a key factor in designing the organic photocatalyst for solar synthesis of H2O2.

Hyejin Kim: Data curation, Formal analysis, Investigation, Visualization, Writing – original draft & Editing. Kyuin Shim: Investigation, Writing – original draft. Kyoung Eun Lee: Formal analysis, Investigation. Jeong Woo Han: Investigation, Methodology, Validation. Yongfa Zhu: Investigation, Methodology, Validation. Wonyong Choi: Conceptualization, Supervision, Writing – review & editing, Funding acquisition.
